text.title: Feed a Pet Mouse
text.head: Feed a Pet Mouse
text.p: Mice are a compact pet to have, but that doesn’t mean they’re low maintenance. They’re an animal that enjoys variety and fun, so keep that in mind when you’re feeding them! Combining liberal amounts of fresh fruits and vegetables and a small amount of mouse pellets for treats throughout the day are great ways to keep your mouse happy and healthy!
text.head: Steps
Feeding Your Mouse Its Daily Food

list.item:
Provide liberal amounts of fresh fruit and vegetables. Fruit and veggies should make up the majority of your mouse’s diet. Mice enjoy variety in their diets, so switch up the fruits and vegetables you give them each day. Some good options include:
Carrots
Broccoli
Cauliflower
Bok Choy
Apples
Bananas
Brussels sprouts
Berries
Cabbage
Corn
Tomatoes
Citrus fruits

Scatter the fruits and veggies inside their cage. It’s in a mouse’s nature to go looking for their food. In the wild, they would spend most of their day on the hunt for a meal. Scattering their food will also keep them entertained.
This will force your mouse to sniff around for its food.
This trick is particularly useful if you have more than once mouse and one is overly protective of its food. Placing the food in a bowl would result in one mouse hogging it all.

Hide the fruits and veggies. To give your mouse a little entertainment with their food, try hiding it. Put the fruit or veggies in a plastic bag or cardboard box - your mouse will have fun ripping and shredding the containers to get the food!

text.head: Offering Your Mouse a Treat

list.item:
Purchase commercial mouse food. This food will only be a small part of your pet mouse’s diet. Buy mouse pellets to offer in small quantities throughout the day.
You can buy mouse food at most pet stores.

Hide small quantities of pellets throughout the day. Hiding the treats allows your mouse to pretend it’s out in the wild. Your mouse will have fun searching for tasty pellet treats in their enclosure. Just make sure you don’t give them too much.

Give your mouse hard treats once a week. Mice can have sharp teeth, and giving them something harder to eat is a great way to wear their teeth down!
An easy option is dog treats, which you can get from any pet store.
If you have a fruit-bearing tree, try one of its branches! Just make sure to bake them for an hour on low heat and wash them to ensure they’re safe for you mouse!

text.head: Tips

list.item: Try feeding your mouse at night. Mice are nocturnal, so they’ll be active and ready to eat!
Keep its food away from your mouse’s bathroom area.
If you don’t want to scatter your mouse’s food, put it in a small ceramic dish. The bowl should be durable enough that it lasts and your mouse doesn’t chew threw it.
Don’t be alarmed if your mouse eats its own poop! It’s actually normal and is necessary for their health. It doesn’t mean you aren’t feeding them enough!

A great thing about mice is they control the amount of food they consume, this means that you don't have to worry about overfeeding. Ensure your mouse has food and fresh water at all times throughout the day. Even if there is still food in the cage, give them fresh food so they won't have to eat old food, it may not taste as great.
